0CA6752C1F41460FA961F0E70DAD3DFF.description: Use correct documentation and design systematically in their own work using instructor-specified formats and style guides (e.g. MLA, APA).

0CB70F01F57C4909B5BDB573BBF7AF4A.description: elect and apply conventions, including multimodal techniques/strategies, to choices for design, style, structure, paragraphing, tone, diction, and vocabulary.

739FB672F92B4D96BB108098949B6CBD.description: Demonstrate contextually appropriate usage and linguistic structures (e.g. syntax, mechanics) in texts they compose.

CAEDEEC8D6E4420EA37B6AFA037B9034.description: Use Edited American English in texts they compose.

EE25C3375B494AC682AED9484C2D457B.description: Demonstrate understanding that conventions differ across communities, disciplines, and genres.

0E9E920509AD4C41BEF928EFC6CD5E5D.description: Implement conventions of academic discourse to produce texts with effective approaches, style, and formats

66610052E1EE4E5F84FA17A22EDF7CB1.description: Knowledge of Discourse Conventions: Conventions are the formal rules and informal guidelines that define genres; they govern such concepts as mechanics, usage, spelling, and citation practices. Writing in academic and professional contexts demands adherence to various conventions of discourse communities that shape readers' and writers' perceptions of correctness and appropriateness.

E4259121EA754DAC8C4F32EA43943A9F.description: Demonstrate knowledge of intellectual property and fair use in applying correct documentation of sources using instructor-specified formats and style guides (e.g. MLA, APA).

991F6FD2E2E04D3FB4D93EF3BCF839B3.description: Synthesize and incorporate information and ideas from sources into compositions using correct summary, paraphrase, and direct quotation, documenting sources to avoid plagiarism and in order to support analytical and/or argumentative purposes.

7E43F24A94B94D2DBD71FDB2CA25835F.description: Select sources appropriate to rhetorical situation, including genre, purpose, audience, and context.

33B8B8F808CC4E0D85771AF176607D51.description: Discern between scholarly and popular sources and evaluate their merit and reliability.

815CB00E769A427D94D2A9EECD7CE2CF.description: Apply research processes to select a topic, develop effective research questions, identify relevant information, and locate sources, using print and digital media/networks.

0BCA5EED754042A694BB5D04A333DDA7.description: Engage independently in extended, formal research processes.

B479141D1F5A493A8EC5A705DA4507EA.description: Research and Information Literacy: Research is the process of promoting inquiry by asking questions, finding appropriate resources, evaluating their value, incorporating them successfully into a text, and developing an understanding of documentation to produce complex, effective texts grounded in evidence. Information literacy encompasses the know-how to use print and digital media to find, select, evaluate, and incorporate sources relevant to personal, scholarly, and professional pursuits.

CD3CAC63B8A14695819176779351D93C.description: Identify different parts of an argument including concession, counter argument/refutation, and confirmation.

1CBE7F2FEE6C4889825FA7C76CD542B0.description: Recognize, gather, and test factual and inferential evidence and avoid logical fallacies in their own writing.

5D627BB2E9E6416EB2C94BEF99686BEF.description: Examine subjects from multiple perspectives and recognize their own biases to formulate and express their own perspective.

BCAF16E29B3D4F0A844172A71AFF3B78.description: Read, comprehend, summarize/paraphrase, analyze, synthesize, and evaluate college-level, cultural texts in a variety of genres.

E93DA8B9E7AF4A818AF3571220D75AE1.description: Develop and apply strategies for critical thinking, reading, and writing processes, including inductive and deductive reasoning.

DC9FBF86FF9F42A4A06AD5E489289C08.description: Analyze and investigate ideas from multiple perspectives and to apply sound reasoning to arguments, their own and others'.

1C11D8854BA44181B96907AEDA2BEDA2.description: Critical Thinking and Argumentation: Critical thinking refers to the ability to investigate ideas and solve problems through analyzing, interpreting and evaluating information, situations, and texts. Critical reading is the practice of making connections between and among texts to develop complexity and discern implications of ideas.

9EF4C0860A44436F848204B4E5DC14DA.description: Demonstrate their understanding of the impact of genre, audience, context, and media on the stance, tone, design, and content of the texts they compose.

47658CA6303448008432EFF73AADD7E0.description: Apply knowledge of rhetorical context to guide their choices of evidence, language, organization, and rhetorical and persuasive strategies in texts they create.

438A2A15566A4670ABB9372104DC6B61.description: Apply their rhetorical knowledge (e.g. audience, purpose, context, genre, and design) to reading texts in a variety of genres and media (e.g. print and digital).

C8C056D1C3A0445D975E63131EFCBA36.description: Apply rhetorical principles (i.e. purpose, audience, stance, genre, context) in order to improve the quality of the texts they create.

6A4A7C0F4CD8497AA1D8AB64166892C4.description: Rhetorical Knowledge and Application: Rhetorical knowledge is the ability to analyze writing, reading, and speaking occasions and make strategic choices to navigate the rhetorical situation. Rhetorical knowledge includes the ability to demonstrate command of purpose, audience, and context.

622CAC67F17A4880990203A59CD6ECC3.description: Revise and edit to improve clarity and correctness of writing.

3BE90E8CE34D48C99BD28B240ADB3F5B.description: Reflect on the rhetorical situation of their compositions and revise to improve.

CA5C9AA69F2541AAAC6A2514019D15BC.description: Effectively apply organizational strategies to open and close their texts and to move the reader between and within ideas, paragraphs, and sentences.

D6DAA78E1B1448A4BB7A0B173803D9D8.description: Examine and analyze their experiences and readings as sources of material for writing and engage with complex ideas, which they incorporate in well-structured prose that considers the purpose, audience, and genre

6D8CF4772044455098AC0FCB08DE818A.description: Independently apply the writing process, including planning, drafting, revising, editing, reflecting, and sharing compositions.

E0501F32C5C44C4BA6D22D7E3441460B.description: Demonstrate the ability to apply a recursive writing process to create a variety of academic texts, including at least one fully documented, original research paper, producing a total of at least 4500-6000 words (approximately 15-20 pages) of polished, graded writing.

3723A42ADE9649CD9750A075F03B4994.description: Writing Processes: Successful writers use multiple composing processes to conceptualize, develop, and finalize projects. Composing processes are both recursive and flexible, adapted to different contexts and occasions to meet purpose and audience.
